articles.title: U.S. FTC sues to block Nvidia deal to buy Arm
articles.summary: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has sued to block Nvidia Corp's more than $80 billion acquisition of British chip technology provider Arm, citing concerns that the deal would give Nvidia undue control over crucial computing technology and designs. This move complicates an already challenging regulatory path for the acquisition, which has faced opposition from the chip industry and scrutiny from British and European Union regulators. The FTC argues the merger would harm competition, reduce innovation, and lead to higher prices by giving Nvidia the ability and incentive to undermine competitors who rely on Arm's technology.

articles.title: Target's gift card sale returns this weekend with 10% off discount. Here's how to save.
articles.summary: Target is bringing back its annual gift card sale this weekend, offering a 10% discount on purchases up to $500 for Target store gift cards. To access the discount, customers must be members of the free Target Circle loyalty program. The gift cards can be used for personal shopping or as gifts and are redeemable in-store or online.

articles.title: Facebook parent grabs another 1M sf in Bay Area
articles.summary: Meta (Facebook's parent company) has leased an additional 1 million square feet of office space in the Bay Area, specifically in Sunnyvale and Burlingame, to reduce employee commute times and support its net-zero carbon emission goal. The lease of four buildings in Sunnyvale, totaling over 700,000 square feet, is considered the largest private-sector office lease in the U.S. this year. This expansion further solidifies Sunnyvale's position as a key office market in Silicon Valley.

articles.title: Nasdaq dives over 2% as tech stocks slide at end of volatile week
articles.summary: Wall Street's major indexes, particularly the Nasdaq, experienced a significant decline as tech stocks slid at the end of a volatile week. This downturn was influenced by mixed jobs data, uncertainty surrounding the Omicron coronavirus variant, and the Federal Reserve's policy tightening signals. Major tech companies such as Apple, Meta Platforms, Alphabet, Amazon, Microsoft, Nvidia, and Tesla all saw their shares fall, contributing to the broader market dip.

articles.title: U.S. sues to block Nvidiaâ€™s $40-billion chip takeover of Arm
articles.summary: U.S. antitrust officials have sued to block Nvidia's proposed $40-billion acquisition of Arm Ltd., citing concerns that the deal would stifle innovation and undermine competition in the semiconductor industry. The Federal Trade Commission argues that the merger would grant Nvidia excessive control over chip designs widely used across various technologies. The acquisition, initially valued at $40 billion in September 2020, has faced regulatory hurdles globally due to Arm's critical role as a technology licensor to hundreds of companies including Nvidia's rivals.

articles.title: Apple loses a top vehicle engineer to flying-taxi startup Archer Aviation
articles.summary: Michael Schwekutsch, a top vehicle engineer previously with Apple's "Project Titan" electric vehicle initiative, has joined Archer Aviation, a startup focused on building flying taxis. His departure comes as Apple tries to accelerate its self-driving car project, sparking discussions among analysts about Apple Car's potential impact on the broader EV market, particularly on Tesla.

articles.title: Apple sues company known for hacking iPhones on behalf of governments
articles.summary: Apple has filed a lawsuit against NSO Group, an Israeli firm that develops software to hack iPhones, alleging that the company weaponizes powerful state-sponsored spyware against innocent users. Apple seeks a permanent injunction to prevent NSO Group from using its software, services, or devices and is seeking damages exceeding $75,000. Additionally, Apple will donate $10 million and any lawsuit damages to organizations combating digital surveillance, while also pledging to inform iPhone users targeted by Pegasus malware.

articles.title: Amazon and Apple handed $225 million in Italian antitrust fines
articles.summary: Italy's antitrust authority has fined Amazon and Apple a total of more than 200 million euros ($225 million) for alleged anti-competitive cooperation. The fines stem from a 2018 agreement that restricted the sale of Apple and Beats products on Amazon.it to only selected resellers, violating EU rules and impacting price competition. Both companies deny wrongdoing and plan to appeal the decision.

articles.title: Apple iPhone 13 Rebates Fail to Deliver for Some Buyers
articles.summary: Some customers are experiencing issues with wireless carriers denying rebates offered to promote new Apple Inc. iPhones, iPads, and Watches. This problem comes years after wireless carriers eliminated deep subsidies for phones, forcing buyers to contend with the full cost of devices. The article also briefly mentions the impact of the omicron variant on Apple and another executive departure.

articles.title: The metaverse needs aggressive regulation
articles.summary: The author, a pioneer in AR/VR technology, argues for aggressive regulation of the metaverse to prevent large corporations from extensive monitoring and manipulation of users. He emphasizes the need to restrict data collection, regulate real-time marketing tactics, and ensure transparency regarding AI-controlled agents and targeted placements. The article warns that without regulation, the metaverse risks becoming an environment where powerful entities exploit user data and emotions for commercial gain.

articles.title: 20-Year Returns: Monster Eats Apple for Breakfast
articles.summary: Over the past 20 years, Monster Beverage Corporation's stock has outperformed major tech companies like Apple and Amazon, increasing by over 100,000 percent. The company, an early entrant in the energy drink market, has grown significantly, recording $1.4 billion in profit on $4.6 billion in sales in 2020. Monster Beverage is now a dominant player in the energy drink market and has recently been in merger talks with Constellation Brands.

articles.title: Market Expert: Fall For Quality, Not Just Tech
articles.summary: A market expert suggests investors prioritize high-quality stocks over solely focusing on big tech names. Mark Mahaney of Evercore ISI advocates for investing in "dislocated high-quality" companies with large total addressable markets and strong innovation, rather than just trading tech stocks. The article highlights the FlexShares US Quality Low Volatility Index Fund (QLV) as an example of an ETF that focuses on quality while managing volatility.

articles.title: Market Expert: Fall For Quality, Not Just Tech
articles.summary: An article discussing the importance of balancing tech investments with high-quality stocks. It highlights Mark Mahaney's "dislocated high-quality" (DHQ) investment tenet and introduces the FlexShares US Quality Low Volatility Index Fund (QLV) as a suitable option for investors seeking quality and reduced volatility.

articles.title: What Stocks Are in QQQ? Rebound Likely, Good Long-Term Pick
articles.summary: The Invesco QQQ Trust Series 1 ETF, which tracks the Nasdaq 100, is a tech-heavy fund that experienced a nosedive following the omicron variant news and inflation concerns in December 2021. Despite this slump, the article suggests that QQQ is likely to recover due to its diverse holdings and past performance, making it a potentially smart long-term investment. The article details the top 20 holdings and the industry breakdown of the ETF.

articles.title: Apple warns Thai activists "state-sponsored attackers" may have targeted iPhones
articles.summary: Apple Inc. issued alert messages to at least six Thai activists and researchers, warning them that their iPhones may have been targeted by "state-sponsored attackers." This comes after Apple filed a lawsuit against Israeli cyber firm NSO Group for alleged surveillance using its Pegasus spyware. The Thai individuals targeted are perceived as critical of the current Thai government.

articles.title: Apple sues Israeli firm NSO Group over spyware
articles.summary: Apple Inc. has filed a lawsuit against Israeli firm NSO Group, accusing it of using its Pegasus spyware to hack Apple devices and enable human rights abuses. This legal action follows previous revelations about Pegasus being used against journalists and activists, and comes after WhatsApp's successful lawsuit against NSO and US sanctions against the company. Apple is seeking financial compensation and a permanent ban on NSO from using its servers and devices, pledging to contribute damages from the lawsuit to groups fighting cyber-surveillance.
